authors.name: Charles Dickens
authors.biography: Charles Dickens was an English writer and social critic. He created some of the world's best-known fictional characters and is regarded by many as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era.

authors.name: Harper Lee
authors.biography: Harper Lee was an American novelist widely known for her novel 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' published in 1960. It won the Pulitzer Prize and has become a classic of modern American literature.

authors.name: F. Scott Fitzgerald
authors.biography: F. Scott Fitzgerald was an American novelist and short story writer, best known for his novel 'The Great Gatsby,' published in 1925. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest American writers of the 20th century.

authors.name: Jane Austen
authors.biography: Jane Austen was an English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique, and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century.

authors.name: George Orwell
authors.biography: George Orwell was an English novelist, essayist, journalist, and critic. His work is characterized by keen intelligence and wit, a profound awareness of social injustice, an intense opposition to totalitarianism, and a passion for clarity in language.

authors.name: Herman Melville
authors.biography: Herman Melville was an American novelist, short story writer, and poet. He is best known for his novel 'Moby-Dick' and his whaling adventure stories.

authors.name: J.D. Salinger
authors.biography: J.D. Salinger was an American writer known for his novel 'The Catcher in the Rye,' a classic of 20th-century American literature. He led a very private life after the success of his novel.

authors.name: Charlotte Brontë
authors.biography: Charlotte Brontë was an English novelist and poet, the eldest of the three Brontë sisters whose novels became classics of English literature.

authors.name: Fyodor Dostoevsky
authors.biography: Fyodor Dostoevsky was a Russian novelist, philosopher, and journalist. His novels explore human psychology in the troubled political, social, and spiritual atmosphere of 19th-century Russia.

authors.name: Oscar Wilde
authors.biography: Oscar Wilde was an Irish poet and playwright. His only novel, 'The Picture of Dorian Gray,' is considered a classic of English literature and his plays are still performed today.

authors.name: J.R.R. Tolkien
authors.biography: J.R.R. Tolkien was an English writer, poet, philologist, and university professor. He is best known for his high fantasy works 'The Hobbit' and 'The Lord of the Rings.'

authors.name: Gabriel García Márquez
authors.fullName: Gabriel José de la Concordia García Márquez
authors.biography: Gabriel García Márquez was a Colombian novelist, short-story writer, screenwriter, and journalist, known for his magical realism style. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1982.

authors.name: Miguel de Cervantes
authors.biography: Miguel de Cervantes was a Spanish writer who is widely regarded as one of the greatest writers in the Spanish language and one of the world's pre-eminent novelists.

authors.name: Leo Tolstoy
authors.biography: Leo Tolstoy was a Russian writer who is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time. His novels 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina' are masterpieces of realist fiction.

authors.name: Emily Brontë
authors.biography: Emily Brontë was an English novelist and poet who is best known for her only novel, 'Wuthering Heights,' now considered a classic of English literature.

authors.name: Mary Shelley
authors.biography: Mary Shelley was an English novelist who wrote the Gothic novel 'Frankenstein,' or 'The Modern Prometheus,' which is now considered one of the earliest examples of science fiction.

authors.name: Homer
authors.biography: Homer is the legendary author of the ancient Greek epic poems the 'Iliad' and the 'Odyssey,' which have profoundly influenced Western literature and culture.

authors.name: Alexandre Dumas
authors.biography: Alexandre Dumas was a French writer famous for his historical adventure novels, including 'The Three Musketeers' and 'The Count of Monte Cristo.'

authors.name: Dante Alighieri
authors.biography: Dante Alighieri was an Italian poet, writer, and philosopher. His most famous work is the epic poem 'Divine Comedy,' widely considered the greatest literary work composed in the Italian language and a masterpiece of world literature.

authors.name: Victor Hugo
authors.biography: Victor Hugo was a French poet, novelist, and dramatist of the Romantic movement. He is considered one of the greatest and best-known French writers.

authors.name: Franz Kafka
authors.biography: Franz Kafka was a German-speaking Bohemian writer, widely regarded as one of the major figures of 20th-century literature. His work, which fuses elements of realism and the fantastic, explores themes of alienation, existential anxiety, guilt, and absurdity.

authors.name: Jonathan Swift
authors.biography: Jonathan Swift was an Anglo-Irish satirist, essayist, political pamphleteer, and poet, famous for works like 'Gulliver's Travels,' 'A Modest Proposal,' and 'A Tale of a Tub.'

authors.name: George Eliot
authors.biography: George Eliot was an English novelist, poet, journalist, and translator, one of the leading writers of the Victorian era. Her novels are known for their realism and psychological insight.

authors.name: Bram Stoker
authors.biography: Bram Stoker was an Irish author best known today for his 1897 Gothic horror novel 'Dracula.' During his lifetime, he was better known as the personal assistant of actor Henry Irving and business manager of the Lyceum Theatre in London.

authors.name: Mark Twain
authors.biography: Mark Twain was an American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer. He is best known for his novels 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer' and 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,' often called the Great American Novels.

authors.name: H.G. Wells
authors.biography: H.G. Wells was an English writer, now best known for his work in the science fiction genre. He was also a prolific writer in many other genres, including contemporary novels, history, politics, and social commentary.

books.title: Great Expectations
books.description: The story of Pip, an orphan who rises from humble beginnings to gentleman status, and his love for the cold-hearted Estella.

books.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
books.description: The story of Scout Finch's childhood in Alabama, her father Atticus Finch, and the trial of a black man accused of raping a white woman.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.description: The story of the mysterious Jay Gatsby and his obsession with the wealthy Daisy Buchanan, set during the Roaring Twenties.

books.title: Pride and Prejudice
books.description: The story of the outspoken Elizabeth Bennet and her love-hate relationship with the wealthy Mr. Darcy.
A dystopian novel set in a totalitarian society where 'Big Brother' watches everyone.

books.title: Moby-Dick
books.description: The voyage of the whaling ship Pequod, commanded by Captain Ahab, who seeks revenge on the giant white sperm whale Moby Dick.

books.title: The Catcher in the Rye
books.description: The story of Holden Caulfield's experiences in New York City after being expelled from prep school.

books.title: Jane Eyre
books.description: The story of the strong-willed orphan Jane Eyre and her love for Mr. Rochester.

books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.description: The psychological thriller of Raskolnikov, a young ex-law student who commits a heinous crime and tries to justify it.

books.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
books.description: The story of a young man, Dorian Gray, who remains young and handsome while his portrait ages and shows the effects of his moral corruption.

books.title: The Hobbit
books.description: The prelude to 'The Lord of the Rings,' following the journey of the hobbit Bilbo Baggins.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.description: The multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo, blending magical and realist elements.

books.title: Don Quixote
books.description: The story of an aging nobleman who, driven mad by reading too many chivalric romances, sets out to revive chivalry under the name Don Quixote.

books.title: Anna Karenina
books.description: The tragic story of the aristocrat Anna Karenina and her affair with the affluent Count Vronsky.

books.title: War and Peace
books.description: A historical novel that chronicles the history of the French invasion of Russia and the impact of the Napoleonic era on Tsarist society through the stories of five Russian aristocratic families.

books.title: Wuthering Heights
books.description: The passionate and tragic love story of Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw, set on the Yorkshire moors.

books.title: Frankenstein
books.description: The story of Victor Frankenstein and the creature he brings to life, exploring themes of ambition and responsibility.

books.title: The Brothers Karamazov
books.description: The philosophical novel exploring faith, doubt, and morality through the story of the Karamazov family.

books.title: The War of the Worlds
books.description: The science fiction novel about an alien invasion of Earth.

books.title: The Odyssey
books.description: The epic poem following the Greek hero Odysseus on his journey home from the Trojan War.

books.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
books.description: The story of Edmond Dantès, a young sailor falsely imprisoned who escapes and seeks revenge.

books.title: Inferno
books.description: The first part of Dante's Divine Comedy, depicting Dante's journey through Hell, guided by the ancient Roman poet Virgil.

books.title: Les Misérables
books.description: The story of Jean Valjean, an ex-convict who seeks redemption while pursued by the relentless Inspector Javert.

books.title: The Metamorphosis
books.description: The novella tells the story of Gregor Samsa, who wakes one morning to find himself transformed into a giant insect-like creature.

books.title: Gulliver's Travels
books.description: The satirical travel narrative of Lemuel Gulliver and his encounters with strange civilizations and societies.

books.title: Middlemarch
books.description: A portrait of the lives of the residents of the fictitious English town of Middlemarch.

books.title: Dracula
books.description: The Gothic horror novel that tells the story of Count Dracula's attempt to move from Transylvania to England so he may find new blood and spread the undead curse.

books.title: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
books.description: The story of Huck Finn's adventures on the Mississippi River with the runaway slave Jim.

news.content: A spy thriller with real authenticity due to its author's previous career as a CIA operative, Damascus Station has proven to be a phenomenal word-of-mouth hit since its publication in January. With its riveting story of forbidden...

news.title: The Best Dark Academia Books
news.content: Abounding in sinister secrets - sometimes magical, sometimes not - locked in the libraries and halls of mysterious educational institutions, dark academia has become a phenomenally successful literary genre. With its...
